metadata.title: Co-enhance bioactive of polymer scaffold with mesoporous silica and nano-hydroxyapatite

sections.text:
ARTICLE HISTORY Received 23 February 2019 Accepted 4 May 2019
KEYWORDS co-enhance; bioactivity; scaffold; hydrophilicity; nano-hydroxyapatite
CONTACT Shuping Peng shuping@csu.edu.cn The Key Laboratory of Carcinogenesis of the Chinese Ministry of Health, Xiangya Hospital, Cancer Research Institute, Central South University, Changsha 410008, China; Youwen Deng drywdeng@csu.edu.cn Department of Emergency Medicine, the Second Xiangya Hospital, Central South University, Changsha 410013, China. 2019 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Scaffolds provide a temporary microenvironment for cell response and new bone formation in bone repair [1,2]. Therefore, scaffold materials should have good biological properties to meet the needs of bone repair. Poly-l-lactic acid (PLLA) has attracted extensive attention as a bone scaffold material on account of its biocompatibility and biodegradability [3,4]. In addition, it was easy to manufacture in diverse shapes and architectures suitable for various bone defects [5]. Nevertheless, the lack of the ability for stimulating biomineralization and cell response limits its further application.
Mesoporous silica Santa Barbara Amorphous-15 (SBA15) possesses large specific surface area and high pore volume, which can provide plentiful recognition sites for cell adhesion [6]. Moreover, the released silicon can induce osteoblast differentiation. However, the low Ca2þ concentration in simulated body fluid (SBF) limits the growth of apatite, though the hydration silica gel layer formed on SBA15 surface provides heterogeneous nucleation sites to induce the formation of apatite. Hydroxyapatite (HA) is an inorganic constituent of the natural bone extracellular matrix [7]. Its degradation increases the Ca2þ concentration, which could accelerate the apatite nucleation and growth. Moreover, its degradation products are alkaline, which may buffer the pH reduction caused by acidic hydrolysate of polymer, avoiding local inflammatory response after transplantation [8].
Several works have taken HA or mesoporous silica as single filler phase to improve the performance of polymer scaffolds. For example, Santos D et al. prepared PLLA-HA scaffolds by electrospinning and found that micro-sized HA imparted bioactive properties to the PLLA scaffolds [9]. Naik A et al. introduced micro-sized HA into poly (lacticco-glycolic acid) (PLGA) scaffolds and found that HA has a buffering effect on the pH reduction resulted by degradation of PLGA [10]. Zakaria SM et al. considered that nHA particles were easily to induce biomineralization compared to larger HA particles due to their large specific surface area [11]. In addition, Shadjou N et al. incorporated mesoporous silica to PLGA and found that it promoted cell response [12]. Nevertheless, to our best knowledge, there was little research on the combined action of nHA and mesoporous silica to co-improve the biological properties of polymer scaffolds.
Selective laser sintering (SLS) is a typical 3D solid rapid freeform manufacturing process, which sinters the powder layer by layer according to the profile of each slice to achieve the fabrication of scaffold with complex profiles and internal porous structural. Therefore, the use of SLS process to prepare complex porous scaffolds has significant advantages. Herein, both nHA and SBA15 were simultaneously incorporated into PLLA to prepare the composite scaffolds by SLS process. The biomineralization ability of the composite scaffolds was assessed by detecting the formation of apatite after immersing in SBF. The biocompatibility was investigated in terms of cell attachment and differentiation. In addition, the degradability and thermal properties were also studied.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text:
Nano-sized HA powder (nHA) with an aspect ratio of about 7 (20 nm in width and 150 nm in length) was purchased from Nanjing Emperor Nano Materials Co., Ltd.
(Jiangsu, China). SBA15 powder with a specific surface area of about 550-600m2/g and mesopore diameter 5–10 nm was supplied by Nanjing XFNANO Materials Tech Co., Ltd. (Nanjing, China). PLLA powder with inherent viscosity 1.46 dl/g was obtained from Jinan Daigang Biomaterial Co., Ltd. (Jinan, China). The morphology of the three kinds of raw materials was shown in Figure 1a–c, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.2. Fabrication of composite scaffolds
sections.text:
Certain amounts of nHA, SBA15 and PLLA powders were separately added into three 300ml beakers containing anhydrous ethanol, followed by subjecting to ultrasonic dispersion for 30min. Subsequently, PLLA-SBA15 solution was prepared by dropping SBA15 solution into PLLA solution under magnetic stirring for 30min. PLLA-SBA15nHA solution was prepared by dropping SBA15 and nHA solution into PLLA solution. Then, the solutions were filtered, followed by drying at 55 C for 12 h. Finally, the composite powders for selective laser sintering were obtained by mechanical milling. The formulations of the composite powders were shown in Table 1
During the preparation of scaffolds, the selective laser sintering system sinters powder layers according to the cross-sectional profiles of the model. After a layer was sintered, the sintering platform descends a height of a powder layer to continue sintering next powder layers. The above mentioned process was cycled until the three dimensional scaffold was obtained with a layer by layer manner. A representative cylindrical interconnected porous scaffold (diameter 15mm x 10mm) with a pore size range of 300–1500lm was shown in Figure 1d. According to the report of Hollister CM team, the enhanced cell adhesion, proliferation and new bone formation were observed on scaffolds with a pore size range of 300-1200 lm. Therefore, the
Figure 1. The morphology of (a) nHA, (b) SBA15 and (c) PLLA original powders; (d) digital photographs of a cylinder porous scaffold.
prepared interconnected porous scaffolds may be important for promoting the ingrowth of new bones and vascularization, the transport of nutrients and waste.

sections.heading: 2.3. Characterization, mechanical and thermal analyses
sections.text:
The fracture surface morphology of scaffolds and the distribution of fillers in matrix were characterized via SEM (Tescan Mira3 Lmu, Co., Czechia) equipped with energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS, Oxford Inc., UK). Prior to SEM observation, scaffolds were subjected to gold sputtering. The compressive strength and modulus of scaffolds (u5 5mm) were measured by a universal mechanical testing machine (Shanghai Zhuoji Instruments Co., Ltd., Shanghai, China) with a loading speed of 0.5mm/min. Each group contains five parallel experiments.
The thermal properties of composite scaffolds were investigated using a simultaneous differential scanning calorimeter/thermogravimetric analysis analyzer (DSC/TGA Nanjin Dazhan Institute of Electromechanical Technology STA-200, China). DSC was used to verify the thermal transitions of the composite scaffolds. About 10mg of specimens was heated from room temperature to 400 C at 20 C/min under nitrogen atmosphere. TGA were used to study the effects of fillers on the thermal decomposition of composite scaffolds. The experiments were carried out at 20 C/min of heating rate from 50 to 600 C under nitrogen atmosphere.

sections.heading: 2.4. Water absorption and degradation assessment
sections.text:
The water absorption and degradation of the composite scaffolds (u10 2mm) were evaluated by immersion test. The composite scaffolds were weighed and recorded as M0, followed by immersing in SBF at 37 C. At selected time point, the composite scaffolds were taken out and wiped with filter paper to remove surface moisture. Subsequently, the composite scaffolds were weighed and recorded as Mwet. Then, they were dried at 55 C to constant weights and recorded as Mdry. The water absorption and weight loss were calculated by the following equations:
water absorption %ð Þ ¼ Mwet Mdry Mdry
100%; (1)
weight loss %ð Þ ¼ M0 Mdry M0
100% (2) The wettability of the composite scaffolds was evaluated by measuring the water contact angle (WCA) by an Attension Theta system (Biolin Scientific Co. Ltd., Stockholm, Sweden). The pH of SBF at selected time point was measured using a pH tester (PHS-2C; JingkeLeici, Shanghai, China).

sections.heading: 2.5. Bioactivity evaluation
sections.text: The bioactivity of composite scaffolds was evaluated by detecting the formation of apatite in SBF. The scaffolds were cleaned with high-frequency ultrasound and then immersed in Petri dish containing SBF at a liquid/solid ratio of 100ml/g. Subsequently, the Petri dishes were cultured in shaking water bath at 37 C for 7, 14 and 21 days. The SBF was renewed every other day. At each selected culture time, the scaffolds were removed and carefully washed with anhydrous ethanol and dried at 55 C for 12 h. The microstructure and chemical groups of composite scaffolds were characterized by SEM and Fourier transform infrared (FTIR, Thermo Scientific Co., Madison, WI, USA) spectroscopy, respectively. The phase composition of composite scaffolds was analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD, D8 Advance, German Bruker Co., Karlsruhe, Germany) in a range of 2h from 10 to 80 at rate of 8 /min.

sections.heading: 2.6. Cell culture
sections.text:
MG63 cells (Cellular Biology Institute, Shanghai, China) were used to evaluate the biological properties of the composite scaffolds. Scaffold samples (u10 2mm) were sterilized using Ultra-violet irradiation before seeding. Cells were inoculated in DMEM supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS) and 1% penicillin/streptomycin sulfate at a density of 1 105 cells/scaffold at damp 95% air atmosphere. The culture medium was renewed every two days. After 1, 3 and 5 days of culture, the scaffolds were removed from the culture medium and carefully rinsed with phosphate buffered saline (PBS). Then, the cells on scaffold were fixed with 3% glutaraldehyde for 30min and dehydrated with a gradient ethanol series. Subsequently, the samples were gold sputtered for SEM observation.
Moreover, the proliferation of cells on the scaffold was quantitatively assessed by the microculture tetrazolium test (MTT). Concretely, 100 ll of MTT solution was immitted to each cell culture plate at a predetermined culture time (1, 3 and 5 days) and incubation was continued for 4 h at 37 C. Subsequently, after removing the supernatant, a certain amount of dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) was added to dissolve the formazan precipitated in intracellular. Finally, the absorbance was obtained at 570 nm using an enzyme labeling device (Amersham, UK) to evaluate the number of living cells. The culture medium without any scaffold was setted as a blank control group to correct the test results. Each set of experiments contained 5 parallel samples to statistically assess cell proliferation.
Besides, the osteogenic differentiation of MG63 cell was analyzed by detecting the level of alkaline phosphatase (ALP) using LabAssay (TM) ALP kit (Wako, Osaka, Japan). After osteoblast-induced culture for 1, 3 and 5 days, adherent cells were removed using 0.25% trypsin solution. And then, the cells were shifted to a new 96- well plate with 1.0ml of culture solution to adhesion and fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde for 30min. After washed with PBS, ALP staining was carried out according to the manufacturer’s instructions. Finally, the stained cells were photographed by an inverted microscope (TE2000U, Nikon, Japan).

sections.heading: 2.7. Statistical analyses
sections.text: The results of experiments were analyzed using One Way ANOVA and expressed in terms of mean ± standard deviation. When P< 0.05, a significant difference was expressed as .

sections.heading: 3.1. Morphology, mechanical and thermal properties
sections.text:
The fracture surface morphology of scaffolds and the distribution of fillers in matrix were shown in Figure 2. The PLLA scaffold used as a control showed in Figure 2a. The PLLA-SBA15 scaffold exhibited a smooth fracture surface (Figure 2b). Comparatively, there were many white spots distributed in matrix of the scaffolds containing nHA (Figure 2c–e). The existence of calcium and phosphorus elements in the EDS spectrum (Figure 2f) indicated that these white spots were nHA. Moreover, nHA was evenly distributed when its content increased from 0 to 10wt. %. However, nHA appeared aggregation when its content reached up to 15wt. %.
The compressive strength, compressive modulus and Vickers hardness of the composite scaffolds were exhibited in Figure 3. The PLLA scaffold was used as a control group with compressive strength of 20.1MPa. When the content of nHA increased from 0 to 10wt. %, the compressive strength and modulus rose from 25.2MPa to 45.7MPa and 2.2GPa to 3.3GPa, respectively (Figure 3a). Meanwhile, Vickers hardness increased from 79.1MPa to 147.7MPa (Figure 3b). Nevertheless, the tendency of compressive strength and modulus began to reverse when the nHA content reached up to 15wt. % (Figure 3a). DSC thermograms of composite scaffolds were reported in Figure 3c. The cold crystallization peak was detected at 90.7 C for PLLA-SBA15 scaffold, whereas it decreased to 85.7 C for PLLA-SBA15-15nHA scaffold. In general, the cold crystallization peaks of the composite scaffolds containing nHA transferred to lower temperatures and the melting peaks shifted to higher temperatures (Figure 3c). The TGA curves of composite scaffolds were given in Figure 3d, from which the coke content was comparable to the loading of fillers. At 95% remaining weight, the decomposition temperature (Td) of composite scaffolds rose from 326 to 356 C as the nHA content increased from 0 to 15wt. %.

sections.heading: 3.2. Hydrophilicity and degradability
sections.text:
Water contact angle (WCA) of the composite scaffolds was given in Figure 4a. Obviously, PLLA scaffold showed a hydrophobic property with a water contact angle of 107.4 ± 3.7 . It was obvious that the introduction of SBA15 and nHA improved the scaffold’s hydrophilicity (with lower WCA). It fell quickly from 95.5 of PLLA-SBA15 to 57.8 of PLLA-SBA15-15nHA scaffolds. The water absorption and weight loss of composite scaffolds were presented in Figure 4b and c, respectively. The water absorption and weight loss increased with the immersing time as well as nHA increasing. During the first 3weeks of the experiments, the water absorption and weight loss increased over time, although the rate of increase slowed down. When it
came to the 4th week, changes in water absorption and weight loss were minimal. The pH change after soaking for different time was illustrated in Figure 4d. After soaking for 28 days, the pH declined from initial value of 7.4 to 6.6 for PLLA scaffold. However, for composite scaffolds contained SBA15 and nHA, the pH showed a slower decrease under equal culture conditions, which provides a favorable microenvironment for cellular response.

sections.heading: 3.3. Biomineralization
sections.text:
The surface morphology of the composite scaffolds after cultivating in SBF was shown in Figure 5. The white particles formed on PLLA-SBA15-10nHA scaffolds were much higher than those formed on PLLA-SBA15 scaffolds after 7 days of culture (Figure 5a and d). The presence of Ca and P peaks in the EDS patterns (Figure 5i and j) indicated the white particles were apatite [13]. The amount of apatite formed on composite scaffolds showed a time-dependent increase (Figure 5c and f). After 21 days of incubation, the PLLA-SBA15-10nHA scaffolds had been covered by the apatite layer (Figure 5f). The Ca/P ratio of the new formed apatite was about 1.63 after 21 days culture, as shown in Figure 5j. The PLLA scaffold used as a control group showed in Figure 5g. The above results indicated that the biomineralization ability of composite scaffolds was enhanced.
The FTIR spectra of the PLLA-SBA15-10nHA scaffolds before and after incubation in SBF were shown in Figure 6a. The characteristic peaks observed at 3571 and 872 cm 1 were respectively corresponding to the stretch mode of hydroxide ion (OH-) and the v2 vibrational mode of carbonate ion (CO3 2-) [14]. Moreover, the
Figure 2. The fracture surface morphologies of scaffolds: (a) PLLA, (b) PLLA-SBA15, (c) PLLA-SBA155nHA, (d) PLLA-SBA15-10nHA and (e) PLLA-SBA15-15nHA; (f) EDS spectrums of the areas with frame I, II and III.
phosphate v4 vibrational band was appeared at positions 567 and 603 cm 1 [15]. The presence of these peaks, especially the carbonate group peaks, indicated the formation of apatite [16,17]. Besides, in the XRD patterns (Figure 6b), the characteristic diffraction peaks of apatite phase were obviously enhanced at 25.8 , 28.5 and 31.6 [18], which further confirmed the results of SEM and FTIR.

sections.heading: 3.4. Cell responses
sections.text:
The morphology of MG63 cell on composite scaffolds after cultured for 1, 3 and 5 days was shown in Figure 7. It was obvious that cells on PLLA and PLLA-SBA15 scaffold exhibited slim shape (Figure 7a and d), whereas cells outspreaded on PLLASBA15-10nHA scaffold (Figure 7g). As incubation progresses, cells presented abundant lamellipodia and were overlapped with each other (Figure 7f, h, and i). These results indicated that the composite scaffolds were facilitated the adhesion and spread of cells.
The MTT assay was performed to quantify analyze cell proliferation on various scaffold samples and the results were shown in Figure 8. It is well known that succinate dehydrogenase in living cell mitochondria can reduce exogenous MTT into purple formazan and deposit it in cells (dead cells do not have this function). Thus, to some
Figure 3. Properties of the composite scaffolds: (a) compressive strength and modulus; (b) Vickers hardness; (c) Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) and (d) Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). p< 0.05 compared to the PLLA scaffolds, and n¼ 5.
extent, the amount of formazan crystals formed is positively correlated with the number of living cells. Compared to the blank control group, cell proliferation on each scaffold was evident during the experiment. Moreover, PLLA-SBA15-10nHA scaffold exhibited the highest cell proliferation, which was significantly higher than the PLLASBA15 and PLLA scaffolds. Moreover, the ALP activity of MG63 cell cultured for 1, 3 and 5 days on scaffolds was given in Figure 9. Obviously, the ALP activity of cells exhibited a time-dependent increase. In contrast, cells cultured on PLLA-SBA1510nHA and PLLA-SBA15 scaffolds had higher ALP activity level than PLLA scaffolds.

sections.heading: 4.1. The effect of fillers on morphology, mechanical and thermal properties
sections.text:
Obviously, with the increase of HA filler content, the white particles in the topography of scaffold surface gradually increased. EDS analysis confirmed that these white particles were the filler HA, and the white particles showed significant aggregation when the content reached 15wt. %. It was well known that nano-materials have a small percolation threshold in polymer materials [19]. When the added amount exceeds the threshold, the nano-materials will agglomerate [20,21]. The above analysis
Figure 4. Hydrophilicity and degradation behaviors of composite scaffolds: (a) water contact angle, (b) water absorption, (c) weight loss and (d) pH value of the SBF.
illuminated that, in this study, the percolation threshold for HA loading in the PLLA matrix was 10wt. %.
Mechanical property is a key indicator for evaluating the performances of bone scaffolds. Compression and indentation testing showed that the compressive strength, modulus and Vickers hardness of the scaffolds increase with filler content when the filler content is no more than 10%. It was attributed to the formation of ion-dipole bonds between the ester groups (C¼O) and the Ca ions, which enhanced the interaction between PLLA and nHA [22,23]. Moreover, the intrinsic rigidity of fillers was beneficial for improving the rigidity of composite scaffolds [24,25]. Nevertheless, when the filler content exceeds the percolation threshold (10 wt. %), the trend in compressive strength and modulus starts to reverse. It can be explained that excessive fillers resulted in agglomeration and subsequent decrease in mechanical strength [26]. The results indicated that the optimum amount of nHA fillers was 10 wt. %.
The DSC results indicated that the addition of filler HA shifts the cold crystallization peak of PLLA to a lower temperature while facilitating the transfer of melting peak to higher one. These results were in line with the conclusion of the
Figure 5. Morphology of scaffolds after cultivating in SBF for 7, 14 and 21 days: (a-c) PLLA-SBA15, (d-f) PLLA-SBA15-10nHA; (g) PLLA scaffold cultivated for 21 days; EDS spectrums of the areas with frame: (h) I, (i) II, (j) III.
research [27] which found that nHA particles made cold crystallization peak of PLLA shift to a low temperature while the melting temperature increased. It may be ascribed to the nHA particles play a nucleating agent in composite, which enhanced nucleation ability and promoted the crystallization [28,29]. What’s more, Ignjatovic N et al. believed that the nHA particles in composites as an obstacle to heat transfer, which was responsible for the increase in thermal decomposition temperature [30].

sections.heading: 4.2. The effect of fillers on hydrophilicity and degradability
sections.text:
The WCA experiments indicated that nHA fillers greatly improved the wettability of composite scaffolds. It was probably due to the fact that the filler HA itself was very hydrophilic. Moreover, the improvement in hydrophilicity of scaffolds was expected to be beneficial for cell responses [31,32]. The changes in water absorption and mass loss of the composite scaffolds can be attributed to the fact that hydrophilic nHA made water easily penetrate into composite scaffolds, which hence promoted the hydrolysis [33]. What’s more, the change of the weight loss became very small after 3 weeks, which may be ascribed to the condition that the weight of apatite formation was comparable to the weight loss of the scaffold degradation [34]. The trend of pH change was similar to the results observed by Yunfei Niu, Fu L [35] and Feng P [21] who found that alkaline ions released from MBG and nHA could neutralize the acidic
Figure 6. (a) XRD and (b) FTIR spectrums of the PLLA-SBA15-10nHA scaffolds before and after immersed in SBF for 21 days; (c) Schematic diagram of biomineralization mechanism.
degradation products of polymer, which was responsible for the delay of pH reduction.

sections.heading: 4.3. Biomineralization mechanism in vitro
sections.text:
Clearly, the SBF test results revealed that the introduction of HA had a positive impact on the biomineralization capacity of the composite scaffolds. Importantly, the biomineralization mechanism of composite scaffolds in SBF can be explained to be the result of electrostatic interaction between ions and a simple schematic diagram was shown in Figure 6c. On the one hand, the negative hydrated silica gel layer on the surface of SBA15 could adsorb cations from the SBF to form apatite nucleation sites (Figure 6c1) [36]. On the other hand, the degradation of nHA released a large amount of calcium ions [37], which provided a rich calcium source to accelerate the formation of nucleation sites (Figure 6c2). Subsequently, a large number of nucleation sites promoted the formation of apatite layer (Figure 6c3 and c4), which could enhance the bio-binding between scaffolds and natural bones [38]. Therefore, the introduced SBA15 and nHA could synergistically improve the bioactivity of PLLA scaffold.
Figure 7. The surface morphology of MG63 cells on the scaffolds after culturing for 1, 3 and 5 days: (a–c) PLLA, (d–f) PLLA-SBA15 and (g–i) PLLA-SBA15-10nHA.

sections.heading: 4.4. The effect of fillers on cell responses
sections.text:
The adherent morphology of the cells on the composite scaffold was directly related to the biocompatibility of the scaffold. Cell culture results showed that the adherent cells on the composite scaffolds had abundant filopodia and lamellipodia, indicating that the scaffolds have good biocompatibility. It was ascribed to the large specific surface of SBA15 and nHA, which provided recognition sites for cell adhesion [39]. Moreover, the improved hydrophilicity and bioactivity of the composite scaffolds were also conducive to the attachment of cells [27,40].
The results of MTT assay indicated that the scaffold material was suitable for cell growth and proliferation, as shown in Figure 8. The addition of SBA15 significantly enhanced the proliferation of cells relative to PLLA scaffold. This might be due to the large specific surface area and high pore volume of the mesoporous structure, which was beneficial for stimulating cell attachment [41]. In addition, the active ion Si released by hydrolysis of SBA15 could promotes cell proliferation [42]. Interestingly, PLLA-SBA15-10nHA scaffold exhibited the highest cell proliferation, which might be attributed to the fact that calcium ions released by nHA and silicon ions released by SBA15 could synergistically promote cell proliferation.
Besides, the ALP activity is an early feature of osteogenic differentiation of cells and plays a key role in early bone formation [43]. The results of ALP staining showed that the ALP activity of the cells gradually increased with the prolongation of culture time, which indicated that the composite scaffold was favorable for the promotion of cell differentiation. It was possibly attributed that the calcium and silicon released from the ternary composite scaffolds could co-stimulate cell gene expression and induces osteoblast differentiation [7,44].
Figure 8. Proliferation of MG63 cells on various scaffold samples after 1, 3 and 5 days of culture. Represents significant difference (p< 0.05), when PLLA-SBA15-10nHA scaffolds as compared to the PLLA-SBA15 scaffolds. #Represents significant difference (p< 0.05), when PLLA-SBA15-10nHA and PLLA-SBA15 scaffolds as compared to the PLLA scaffolds.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this work, PLLA-SBA15-nHA scaffolds were prepared via selective laser sintering. In bioactivity assessment experiments, the composite scaffolds exhibited a good biomineralization ability to induce apatite deposition. Moreover, cell culture manifested that the composite scaffolds promoted cell adhesion and induced high level ALP activity. The alkaline degradation product of nHA could slow down the pH reduction of SBF. In addition, the composite scaffolds also have improved hydrophilicity and enhanced mechanical properties. Therefore, the PLLA-SBA15-nHA scaffolds may have potential applications in bone repair.
Funding

Figure 9. ALP staining of MG63 cells after culturing on PLLA (a-c), PLLA-SBA15 (d-f) PLLA-SBA1510nHA (g-i) scaffolds for 1, 3 and 5 days, respectively.
Provincial Science and Technology Plan (2017RS3008); Shenzhen Science and Technology Plan Project (JCYJ20170817112445033); (6) National Postdoctoral Program for Innovative Talents (BX201700291); (7) The China Postdoctoral Science Foundation (2018M632983); (8) The Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities of Central South University (2018ZZTS145).

referenceMentions.context: Scaffolds provide a temporary microenvironment for cell response and new bone formation in bone repair [1,2].
Scaffolds provide a temporary microenvironment for cell response and new bone formation in bone repair [1,2].
Poly-l-lactic acid (PLLA) has attracted extensive attention as a bone scaffold material on account of its biocompatibility and biodegradability [3,4].
Poly-l-lactic acid (PLLA) has attracted extensive attention as a bone scaffold material on account of its biocompatibility and biodegradability [3,4].
In addition, it was easy to manufacture in diverse shapes and architectures suitable for various bone defects [5].
Mesoporous silica Santa Barbara Amorphous-15 (SBA15) possesses large specific surface area and high pore volume, which can provide plentiful recognition sites for cell adhesion [6].
Hydroxyapatite (HA) is an inorganic constituent of the natural bone extracellular matrix [7].
Moreover, its degradation products are alkaline, which may buffer the pH reduction caused by acidic hydrolysate of polymer, avoiding local inflammatory response after transplantation [8].

On the other hand, the degradation of nHA released a large amount of calcium ions [37], which provided a rich calcium source to accelerate the formation of nucleation sites (Figure 6c2).
Subsequently, a large number of nucleation sites promoted the formation of apatite layer (Figure 6c3 and c4), which could enhance the bio-binding between scaffolds and natural bones [38].

metadata.abstractText: Mesoporous silica Santa Barbara Amorphous-15 (SBA15) and nanohydroxyapatite (nHA) were introduced in poly-l-lactic acid (PLLA) scaffold fabricated by selective laser sintering to co-enhance the bioactivity. On the one hand, the active elements silicon and calcium released respectively by the degradation of SBA15 and nHA were favorable for stimulating cell response. On the other hand, the hydrated silica gel layer derived from SBA15 could adsorb calcium ions released from nHA, thereby co-promoting apatite nucleation and growth. The experimental results showed that the formation of bone-like apatite on the scaffold was accelerated under simulated body fluid, indicating a good biomineralization capacity. Moreover, the scaffold demonstrated a good cell response in promoting the attachment of cell and the expression of alkaline phosphatase activity. Besides, SBA15 and nHA not only improved the hydrophilicity of the scaffold (the water contact angle changed from 107.4 to 57.8 ), but also retarded the pH reduction by neutralizing the acidic hydrolysate of PLLA. These results indicated that the PLLA-SBA15nHA scaffold may be potential candidates for bone repair. ARTICLE HISTORY Received 23 February 2019 Accepted 4 May 2019
